channel.title: Static ip?
channel.description: how can i host my server cause if im correct the "no-ip duc" gives you a dynamic ip so i cant host it off that right?

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

dan.:

i think its working now i was forgetting to run the server but on canyouseeme.org i put the port in etc and normally says its timed out now it said succeful and says Your ISP is not blocking port 43594 does that mean its online?

For utilities like canyouseeme to work, you must have an application listening on the port you’re testing (as they use http://php.net/manual/en/function.fsockopen.php).

Edit: does ‘tekato’ ring a bell to you? If not forget I mentioned it at all.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @dan1 dan.
item.description:

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

dan.:

i went through a tutorial to make my ip static which is 192.168.1.6 so i sent that as my port forwarding ip but on my no-ip it says th ip is 2.96.104.136 which is a dynamic ip but why wont it change to my ip cause while it dynamic my ports dont work therefore my server wont work

192.168.1.6 is your internal IP.
2.96.104.136 is your external IP.

See (for internal IP explanation):

en.wikipedia.org

Private network

In the Internet addressing architecture, a private network is a network that uses private IP address space, following the standards set by RFC 1918 for Internet Protocol Version 4 (IPv4), and RFC 4193 for Internet Protocol Version 6 (IPv6). These addresses are commonly used for home, office, and enterprise local area networks (LANs). Private IP address spaces were originally defined in an effort to delay IPv4 address exhaustion, but they are also a feature of IPv6 where exhaustion is not an issue...

See (to verify your external IP):

WhatIsMyIP.com®

What Is My IP? Shows your real IP - IPv4 - IPv6 - WhatIsMyIP.com®

IPv4 Address, IPv6 Address, IP Address Lookup, Change IP, Hide IP, IP WHOIS, Internet Speed Test, Trace An Email, Host Name Lookup, User Agent, Server Headers Check, IP Commands

Read full topic

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @dan1 dan.
item.description:
@dan1 wrote:

i went through a tutorial to make my ip static which is 192.168.1.6 so i sent that as my port forwarding ip but on my no-ip it says th ip is 2.96.104.136 which is a dynamic ip but why wont it change to my ip cause while it dynamic my ports dont work therefore my server wont work

Read full topic

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

dan.:

ive set up no-ip but i need to portforward but i dont have a static ip so it wont go to the port?

I really suggest you read up on basic networking. Specifically how a router’s NAT works and what No-ip and such services do.

Read full topic

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @dan1 dan.
item.description:
@dan1 wrote:

ive set up no-ip but i need to portforward but i dont have a static ip so it wont go to the port?

Read full topic

item.title: Static ip?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“dan., post:5, topic:402567”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=499624.msg3653905#msg3653905 date=1309902273]

A static IP is obtained via whoever administrates your network. This means that you can have static clients on your own internal network behind a router - because you delegate that range. However, a external IP (not behind a NAT) is delegated by your ISP; so if you’re looking for a static external IP, go talk to your ISP.

i need a static ip to host a server right?

It’s optimal, but not necessary - I recommend using a domain (hostname) to point to whatever your current IP is.
[/quote]
hostname? you mean like no-ip? cause thats what im using but i cant forward my ports with it O.o[/quote]
No-ip is one service that does what I’ve mentioned. And that has nothing to do with port-forwarding.

Read full topic
